item.title: Procedural field of bolders by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
Here's another fun little procedural art experiment. I generated a couple of boulders in houdini and scattered them in cryengine using the vegetation scattering system. It still feels weird to give away so much control over the look and placement of assets and let the sliders do the job. a.k.a "Move the sliders until it looks good"
The results weren't that great in the beginning and it took a while to find a decent looking spot. After a bit of cleanup (there was a lot of overlapping geo in some areas) I had a somewhat presentable corner.
Materials were done in substance designer and applied in painter with a super simple smart material.

Thanks for dropping by!
item.content:encoded:
Here's another fun little procedural art experiment. I generated a couple of boulders in houdini and scattered them in cryengine using the vegetation scattering system. It still feels weird to give away so much control over the look and placement of assets and let the sliders do the job. a.k.a "Move the sliders until it looks good"
The results weren't that great in the beginning and it took a while to find a decent looking spot. After a bit of cleanup (there was a lot of overlapping geo in some areas) I had a somewhat presentable corner.
Materials were done in substance designer and applied in painter with a super simple smart material.

Thanks for dropping by!

item.title: Procedural Mossy Rocks by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
Hey! Here's another fun Houdini exercise based on the procedural comets that I have made earlier: https://www.artstation.com/artwork/PmKgeo

Like the comets, the mossy rocks were created proceduraly.
Materials were done in Substance Designer, geometry in Houdini. Rendering was done in Marmoset
item.content:encoded:
Hey! Here's another fun Houdini exercise based on the procedural comets that I have made earlier: https://www.artstation.com/artwork/PmKgeo

Like the comets, the mossy rocks were created proceduraly.
Materials were done in Substance Designer, geometry in Houdini. Rendering was done in Marmoset

Procedural Rocks

item.title: Procedural Comets by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
It's not a secret that I love comets & astroids This time I wanted to build them fully procedurally.
Highpoly, lowpoly, UVs were done in Houdini. Materials were done in Substance Designer and then applied in Substance Painter using a smart material. Rendered in Marmoset. It takes roughly 5 minutes to generate a new comet including the texture baking.
item.content:encoded:
It's not a secret that I love comets & astroids This time I wanted to build them fully procedurally.
Highpoly, lowpoly, UVs were done in Houdini. Materials were done in Substance Designer and then applied in Substance Painter using a smart material. Rendered in Marmoset. It takes roughly 5 minutes to generate a new comet including the texture baking.

View this on ArtStation
Marcel Schaika on ArtStation

item.title: Hunt: Showdown - Nicholls Prison by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
Nicholls Prison is a location on the 2nd map. I was responsible for its art production: Layout, blockout, build modular architecture, set dressing. Screenshots were taken directly in the game. I worked closely with level designer Matthias Otto, who was responsible for the technical setup of the level and the general game design aspect of it. I built the compound in a modular fashion using mostly tileable textures. I also worked closely with Ivo Nies, who supported me with tons of great concept art!
https://www.artstation.com/artwork/2xqq4g
Matthias Wagner did a lot of the prison props like those beautiful cell doors: https://www.artstation.com/matiswagner

Art Direction: Magnus Larbrant.

Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek<3
item.content:encoded:

The prison brick textures are based on a substance that was done earlier in production by Michel Kooper.

item.title: Hunt: Showdown - Misc by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
This page shows some look dev. work I did on Hunt: Showdown. Most of the assets were done by the fantastic Hunt art department.

Art Direction: Magnus Larbrant.

Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of the textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek <3

Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of the textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek <3

This scenes was created to explore the look and feel of a close up interior shot. I used all available assets from the art team and only did the composition, lighting and some minor color tweaks here and there.


This scenes was created to explore the look and feel of a close up interior shot. I used all available assets from the art team and only did the composition, lighting and some minor color tweaks here and there.


This scene was created to define the vibe of an interior scene. I used all available assets from the art team to build it.


This scene was created to define the vibe of an exterior scene. I used all available assets from the art team to build it.


This scene was created to explore a foggy lighting scenario. I used all available assets from the art team to build it.

item.title: Hunt: Showdown - Port Reeker by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
Port Reeker is a location on the first map of "Hunt: Showdown". I was responsible for its art production. This includes, blockouts, layout, level art & set dressing. Screenshots were taken directly in the game editor. I worked in close relationship with level designer Hussein Dari, who was responsible for the technical setup of the level and the general game design aspect of it. I also worked with Artem Shumnik, who supported me with tons of great concept art!
https://www.artstation.com/artwork/Xlgdy

Art Direction: Magnus Larbrant

Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of the textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek <3

item.title: Hunt: Showdown - Swamp Cabins by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
The swamp cabins set is a generic architecture set that was used to create smaller manmade structures in the game.
The set was mostly used as a filler set for spaces between and within compounds. I built it in a modular fashion using tileable textures.
The screenshots were taken directly from the game.

Art direction: Magnus Larbrant
Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of the textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek <3
item.content:encoded:
The swamp cabins set is a generic architecture set that was used to create smaller manmade structures in the game.
The set was mostly used as a filler set for spaces between and within compounds. I built it in a modular fashion using tileable textures.
The screenshots were taken directly from the game.

Art direction: Magnus Larbrant
Hunt is a team effort! We share a lot of the textures, props, models etc... It's a great pleasue to work with those super talented people at Crytek <3

item.description:
Hey!

This tutorial requires some basic knowledge of Mavelous Designer. If you have trubble following me here, I would recommend to first check out my beginners tutorial "An introduction to Marvelous Designer"

item.title: Hunt: Showdown, E3 2017 by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
I had the pleasure to create the screenshots for the E3 reveal of our new project Hunt: Showdown.
I was responsible for the set dressing, composition and the final light setup.
Art assets come from the fantastic art team at Crytek <3
All shots were created with in-game pre-alpha content only. No photoshop or additional "beauty" lights have been used.

Learn more about the game at: https://www.huntshowdown.com/
item.content:encoded:
I had the pleasure to create the screenshots for the E3 reveal of our new project Hunt: Showdown.
I was responsible for the set dressing, composition and the final light setup.
Art assets come from the fantastic art team at Crytek <3
All shots were created with in-game pre-alpha content only. No photoshop or additional "beauty" lights have been used.

Learn more about the game at: https://www.huntshowdown.com/

item.title: Tutorial: An introduction to Marvelous Designer by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
"An introduction to Marvelous Designer"

Get it here on Flipped Normals: https://flippednormals.com/downloads/an-introduction-to-marvelous-designer/
Get it here on Cubebrush: https://cubebrush.co/mschaika/products/rh2dng-hADR
Get it here on Gumroad: https://gumroad.com/l/VqgGv#

Have you been thinking about learning Marvelous Designer to enrich your environment and prop work with cool cloth simulations?
Then I might have the right tutorial for you!

Experience in MD is not required. I will introduce and guide you through all important features of this amazing tool, step by step.
You have access to all source files so you can easily follow and understand every single step.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Discarded moon base studies and ideas by Marcel Schaika
item.description:
I've beenn working on/off on a small moon base for quite some time now . I explored a lot of different ideas and directions and
I though It would be cool for people to see how things have developed and what ideas fell through during the process. So here's a big dump of dismissed ideas and assets
